og_response: I am in this commanded to deliver    The noble duke of Clarence to your hands.    I will not reason what is meant hereby    Because I will be guiltless from the meaning.    There lies the duke asleep, and there the keys.     [He hands them the keys]     Ill to the king and signify to him    That thus I have resigned my charge to you.

translated_dialog: This warrant commands me to deliver the noble Duke of Clarence into your hands. I won't ask what this means, for I'd rather not know about something that might make me guilty later. There's the duke, sleeping, and here are the keys. [He hands them the keys] I'll go to the king and tell him that I've handed over my prisoner to you.
og_response: You may, sir. 'Tis a point of wisdom. Fare you well.

translated_dialog: You may do that, sir. It's a wise idea. Farewell.
og_response: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?

translated_dialog: Well, should I stab him as he sleeps?
og_response: No. Hell say twas done cowardly, when he wakes.

translated_dialog: No. When he wakes up he'll say that we killed him like cowards.
og_response: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.

translated_dialog: Why, he won't be waking up until Judgment Day.
og_response: Why, then hell say we stabbed him sleeping.

translated_dialog: Well, then on Judgment Day he'll say that we stabbed him in his sleep.
og_response: The urging of that word judgment hath bred a kind of remorse in me.

translated_dialog: That word "judgment" has made me feel a little bit guilty.
og_response: What, art thou afraid?

translated_dialog: What, are you afraid?
og_response: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.

translated_dialog: Not afraid to kill him, since we have a warrant for it. But I'm afraid to be damned for killing him. No warrant can protect me from that.
og_response: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

translated_dialog: I thought you were sure about this.
og_response: So I amto let him live.

translated_dialog: I am surethat we should let him live.
og_response: Ill back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

translated_dialog: I'll go back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
og_response: Nay, I prithee stay a little. I hope this passionate humor of mine will change. It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.

translated_dialog: No, please, stay a minute. I'm hoping that my compassionate mood will pass. It usually only lasts about twenty seconds.
og_response: How dost thou feel thyself now?

translated_dialog: How are you feeling now?
og_response: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.

translated_dialog: Honestly, my conscience is still troubling me a bit.
og_response: Remember our reward when the deeds done.

translated_dialog: Remember the reward we'll get when the deed is done.
og_response: Zounds, he dies! I had forgot the reward.

translated_dialog: By God, he must die! I had forgotten about the reward.
og_response: Wheres thy conscience now?

translated_dialog: Where's your conscience now?
og_response: O, in the duke of Gloucesters purse.

translated_dialog: Oh, in the Duke of Gloucester's purse.
og_response: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.

translated_dialog: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, your conscience will fly out.
og_response: 'Tis no matter. Let it go. Theres few or none will entertain it.

translated_dialog: That won't matter. Let it fly off. No one will take it in.
og_response: What if it come to thee again?

translated_dialog: What if it comes back to you?
og_response: Ill not meddle with it. It makes a man a coward: a mancannot steal but it accuseth him; a man cannot swear but it checks him; a man cannot lie with his neighbors wife but it detects him.   'Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a mans bosom. It fills a man full of obstacles.   It made me once restore a purse of gold that by chance I found. It beggars any man that keeps it.   It is turned out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing, and every man that means to live well endeavors to trust to himself and live without it.

translated_dialog: I won't bother with it. A conscience makes a man a coward. A man can't steal without it accusing him; he can't swear without it restraining him; he can't sleep with his neighbor's wife without it exposing him. It's a blushing, shamefaced spirit that betrays a man's heart. It fills him with obstacles. It once made me return a purse full of gold that I found. A conscience can turn any man into a beggar. It's been thrown out of towns and cities like a dangerous enemy. Any man who wants to live well should trust only himself, and live without his conscience.
og_response: Zounds, tis even now at my elbow, persuading me not tokill the duke.

translated_dialog: My God, now it's even at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.
og_response: Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not. He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

translated_dialog: Ignore your conscience, and think about the devil instead. He might flatter you, but he won't make you sad.
og_response: I am strong-framed. He cannot prevail with me.

translated_dialog: I'm strong-willed. My conscience won't overcome me.
og_response: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation. Come, shall we fall to work?

translated_dialog: Spoken like a brave man who values his reputation. Come, shall we get to work?
og_response: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.

translated_dialog: Hit him on the head with the hilt of your sword, and then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room.
og_response: O excellent device and make a sop of him.

translated_dialog: Oh, what an excellent planwe'll make him a sponge for the wine.
og_response: Soft, he wakes.

translated_dialog: Quiet, he's waking up.
og_response: Strike!

translated_dialog: Strike!
og_response: No, well reason with him.

translated_dialog: No, we'll talk to him first.
og_response: Where art thou, keeper? Give me a cup of wine.

translated_dialog: Where are you, jailer? Give me a cup of wine.
og_response: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.

translated_dialog: You'll have plenty of wine soon enough, my lord.
og_response: In Gods name, what art thou?

translated_dialog: In God's name, who are you?
og_response: A man, as you are.

translated_dialog: A man, like you are.
og_response: But not, as I am, royal.

translated_dialog: But not a royal man, as I am.
og_response: Nor you, as we are, loyal.

translated_dialog: And you're not a loyal man, as we are.
og_response: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

translated_dialog: You speak with authority, but you look like a common man.
og_response: My voice is now the kings, my looks mine own.

translated_dialog: I'm speaking for the kingmy looks are my own.
og_response: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak! Your eyes do menace me. Why look you pale?Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

translated_dialog: Your words are so dark and threatening! Your eyes menace me. Why do you look so pale? Who sent you here? Why have you come?
og_response: To, to, to

translated_dialog: To, to, to
og_response: To murder me?

translated_dialog: To murder me?
og_response: Ay, ay.

translated_dialog: Yes, yes.
og_response: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it. Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?

translated_dialog: You hardly have the heart to tell me, so you must not have the heart to do it. Besides, my friends, have I offended you?
og_response: Offended us you have not, but the king.

translated_dialog: You haven't offended usyou offended the king.
og_response: I shall be reconciled to him again.

translated_dialog: He and I will be reconciled again.
og_response: Never, my lord. Therefore prepare to die.

translated_dialog: Never, my lord. So prepare to die.
og_response: Are you drawn forth among a world of men    To slay the innocent? What is my offense?    Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?    What lawful quest have given their verdict up    Unto the frowning judge?   Or who pronounced    The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death    Before I be convict by course of law?    To threaten me with death is most unlawful.    I charge you, as you hope to have redemption,    By Christs dear blood shed for our grievous sins,    That you depart, and lay no hands on me.   The deed you undertake is damnable.

translated_dialog: Have you been chosen specially, just to kill the innocent? What is my offense? Where is the evidence against me? What jury has sentenced me in front of a frowning judge? Or who has pronounced this death sentence on me before I could be convicted by a court of law? To threaten me with death is wrong. If you hope to be saved by Christ's dear bloodwhich was shed for our sinsthen I tell you to leave now without touching me. The deed you plan to do is punishable with damnation.
og_response: What we will do, we do upon command.

translated_dialog: What we do, we do because we were commanded to.
og_response: And he that hath commanded is our king.

translated_dialog: And the one who has commanded us is our king.
og_response: Erroneous vassals, the great King of kings    Hath in the tables of His law commanded    That thou shalt do no murder.   Will thou then    Spurn at His edict and fulfill a mans?    Take heed, for He holds vengeance in His hand    To hurl upon their heads that break His law.

translated_dialog: You misguided subjects, the great King of KingsGodhas said in his Ten Commandments that "you shall not murder." Will you then disobey God's commandment just to obey a man's? Beware, for God holds vengeance in his hand, waiting to smite those who break his laws.
og_response: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee    For false forswearing and for murder too.    Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight    In quarrel of the house of Lancaster.

translated_dialog: And he will smite you with that same vengeance for breaking your oaths, and for murder too. You swore a holy oath to fight for the house of Lancaster.
og_response: And, like a traitor to the name of God,Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade Unrippedst the bowels of thy sovereigns son.

translated_dialog: Andlike a traitor to the name of Godyou broke that vow, and with your treacherous sword you ripped open the chest of your king, Henry's, son Edward.
og_response: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.

translated_dialog: Whom you were sworn to cherish and defend.
og_response: How canst thou urge Gods dreadful law to usWhen thou hast broke it in such dear degree?

translated_dialog: How can you preach about God's laws to us when you have broken them to such an extreme degree?
og_response: Alas! For whose sake did I that ill deed?    For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.    He sends you not to murder me for this,    For in that sin he is as deep as I.    If God will be avengèd for this deed,    O, know you yet He doth it publicly!    Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm;    He needs no indirect or lawless course    To cut off those that have offended Him.

translated_dialog: Alas! But for whose sake did I do that terrible deed? For my brother Edward, for his sake. He can't be sending you to murder me for the prince's deathbecause in that, he is just as guilty as I am. If God intends to punish me for this deed, oh, you know that he will do it publicly! God has no need for indirect or illegal methods of killing those who have offended him.
og_response: Who made thee then a bloody ministerWhen gallant-springing, brave Plantagenet, That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?

translated_dialog: Who provoked you to kill that brave and lively youth, Prince Edward?
og_response: My brothers love, the devil, and my rage.

translated_dialog: My brother's love; the devil; and my rage.
og_response: Thy brothers love, our duty, and thy faultsProvoke us hither now to slaughter thee.

translated_dialog: Well, your brother's love; our duty; and your own crimes now provoke us to kill you.
og_response: If you do love my brother, hate not me.    I am his brother, and I love him well.    If you are hired for meed, go back again,    And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,    Who shall reward you better for my life    Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

translated_dialog: If you really love my brother Richard, then don't hate me. I am his brother, and I love him very much. If you're hired to do this for money, then go back again and talk to my brother the Duke of Gloucester. He will reward you better for sparing my life than King Edward will for news of my death.
og_response: You are deceived. Your brother Gloucester hates you.

translated_dialog: You are deceived. Your brother Richard hates you.
og_response: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.Go you to him from me.

translated_dialog: Oh, no, he loves me and cherishes me. Go to him from me.
og_response: Ay, so we will.

translated_dialog: Yes, so we will.
og_response: Tell him, when that our princely father York    Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm,    And charged us from his soul to love each other,    He little thought of this divided friendship.    Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

translated_dialog: Tell him that when our princely father, the Duke of York, blessed his three sons and commanded us to love each other, he never imagined that our friendship would end up divided like this. Remind Richard of this, and he will weep.
og_response: Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.

translated_dialog: Yes, he'll weep stones, as he taught us to do.
og_response: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.

translated_dialog: Oh, do not slander him, for he is a kind man.
og_response: As snow in harvest. Come, you deceive yourself.'Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.

translated_dialog: As kind as snow during harvest time. Come, you're deceiving yourself. It's Richard who sent us here to kill you.
og_response: It cannot be, for he bewept my fortune,And hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobsThat he would labor my delivery.

translated_dialog: It cannot be. He wept over my imprisonment. And he hugged me in his arms, and swore while sobbing that he would work to have me released.
og_response: Why, so he doth, when he delivers youFrom this earths thralldom to the joys of heaven.

translated_dialog: Why, that's what he didand now you'll be released from the prison of earth, to be free among the joys of heaven.
og_response: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

translated_dialog: Make your peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
og_response: Have you that holy feeling in your souls    To counsel me to make my peace with God,    And art you yet to your own souls so blind    That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?    O sirs, consider: they that set you on    To do this deed will hate you for the deed.

translated_dialog: You have enough holy feeling in your souls to advise me to make my peace with God. But you're still willing to disobey God by murdering me? Oh, sirs, consider this: those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it.
og_response: [to FIRST MURDERER]  What shall we do?

translated_dialog: [To the FIRST MURDERER] What should we do?
og_response: Relent, and save your souls.    Which of youif you were a prince's son    Being pent from liberty, as I am now    If two such murderers as yourselves came to you,    Would you not entreat for life?   Ay, you would beg,    Were you in my distress.

translated_dialog: Give up this attempt, and save your souls. Which of you, if you were in my positiona prince's son in prison, and two murderers like yourselves came to youwouldn't beg for your life? Yes, you would beg, if you were in my situation.
og_response: Relent? No. 'Tis cowardly and womanish.

translated_dialog: Give up? No. That's cowardly and womanish.
og_response: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.     [to SECOND MURDERER]     My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks.    O, if thine eye be not a flatterer,    Come thou on my side and entreat for me.    A begging prince what beggar pities not?

translated_dialog: But to not give up, and murder me, is beastly, savage, and devilish.
og_response: Look behind you, my lord.

translated_dialog: Look behind you, my lord.
og_response: Take that, and that.  [stabs CLARENCE]  If all this will not do,Ill drown you in the malmsey butt within.

translated_dialog: Take that, and that. [He stabs CLARENCE] If all this won't do the job, then I'll drown you in that wine barrel.
og_response: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched. How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my handsOf this most grievous murder.

translated_dialog: A bloody deed, and desperately done. I wish I could wash my hands of this sad murder, as Pontius Pilate did.
og_response: How now? What meanst thou, that thou helpst me not?By heavens, the duke shall know how slack you have been.

translated_dialog: What's going on? What's wrong with you, that you didn't help me? By God, the duke will hear about how you've neglected your duty.
og_response: I would he knew that I had saved his brother. Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say,For I repent me that the duke is slain.

translated_dialog: I wish he could hear that I had saved his brother. You take the reward, and tell him what I've said. I'm sorry that the Duke of Clarence has been killed.
og_response: So do not I. Go, coward as thou art.    Well, Ill go hide the body in some hole    Till that the duke give order for his burial.    And when I have my meed, I will away,    For this will out, and then I must not stay.

translated_dialog: Well, now I've done a good day's work. You must all maintain this unity and friendship. Every day I expect a messenger of God to bear me away from here, and I can leave for heaven in peace now that my friends have made their peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand. Don't just hide your hatred under a facade of friendship. Swear your love for each other.
og_response: [taking HASTINGSs hand]  By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate, And with my hand I seal my true hearts love.

translated_dialog: [Taking HASTINGS' hand] By heaven, my soul is now cleansed of all grudges and hatred. With this handshake I swear that this love is true.
og_response: So thrive I as I truly swear the like.

translated_dialog: So may I prosper, as I swear the same thing.
og_response: Take heed you dally not before your king,    Lest He that is the supreme King of kings    Confound your hidden falsehood, and award    Either of you to be the others end.

translated_dialog: Make sure that you don't mock your king by lying in front of him. Otherwise God, the supreme King of Kings, will uncover your hidden lies and cause you to be the death of each other.
og_response: So prosper I as I swear perfect love.

translated_dialog: I swear perfect love for Rivers, or may I never prosper.
og_response: And I as I love Hastings with my heart.

translated_dialog: And I love Hastings with all my heart.
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]     Madam, yourself is not exempt in this,    Nor you, son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you.    You have been factious one against the other.    Wife, love Lord Hastings. Let him kiss your hand,    And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

translated_dialog: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Madam, you're not exempt from this.
og_response: There, Hastings, I will never more rememberOur former hatred, so thrive I and mine.

translated_dialog: Here's my hand, Hastings. I will forget all our past hatred for each other, and may we both prosper in the future.
og_response: Dorset, embrace him.Hastings, love Lord Marquess.

translated_dialog: Now Dorset, hug Hastings. Hastings, befriend Lord Marquess of Dorset.
og_response: This interchange of love, I here protest,Upon my part shall be inviolable.

translated_dialog: I swear that I will never go back on this exchange of love and friendship.
og_response: And so swear I.

translated_dialog: And I swear it too.
og_response: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wifes alliesAnd make me happy in your unity.

translated_dialog: Now, princely Buckingham, seal this friendship by embracing my wife's allies, and through your unity make me happy.
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]     Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate    Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love    Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me    With hate in those where I expect most love.    When I have most need to employ a friend,    And most assurèd that he is a friend,    Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile    Be he unto me:   this do I beg of God    When I am cold in love to you or yours.

translated_dialog: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] If I should ever come to hate your Grace, and fail to love and cherish you and your relatives, may God punish me by making me find hatred where I expect love. When I most need a friend and am sure that my friends are trustworthy, may they turn false, treacherous, and full of deceit. I beg that God will do this if I ever lose my love for you and your allies.
og_response: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,    Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.    There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here    To make the blessèd period of this peace.

translated_dialog: Noble Buckingham, your vow of friendship is like medicine for my sickly heart. Now all we need is my brother Richard to bring the blessed conclusion to this time of peace.
og_response: And in good time,Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.

translated_dialog: And just in time, here comes Richard with Sir Richard Ratcliffe.
og_response: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen,And, princely peers, a happy time of day.

translated_dialog: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen. And I'm happy to see you too, my princely peers.
og_response: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.    Brother, we have done deeds of charity,    Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,    Between these swelling, wrong-incensèd peers.

translated_dialog: Happy indeedthat's the way we've spent the day. Brother, we have done deeds of love, turning enmity to peace and hatred to love between these misguidedly angry nobles.
og_response: A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.    Amongst this princely heap, if any here    By false intelligence, or wrong surmise    Hold me a foe,    If I unwittingly, or in my rage,    Have aught committed that is hardly borne    By any in this presence,   I desire    To reconcile me to his friendly peace.    'Tis death to me to be at enmity;    I hate it, and desire all good mens love.    First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,    Which I will purchase with my duteous service;    Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham,    If ever any grudge were lodged between us;    Of you, Lord Rivers, and Lord Gray of you,    Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed of all!    I do not know that Englishman alive    With whom my soul is any jot at odds    More than the infant that is born tonight.    I thank my God for my humility.

translated_dialog: A blessed labor, my sovereign lord. If any among this princely group considers me an enemywhether from lies they've heard about me, or because by accident or in anger I've done something to give offenseI want us to be reconciled and become peaceful friends. To be enemies with anyone is like death to me; I hate it, and only desire the love of all good men.
og_response: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.    I would to God all strifes were well compounded.    My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness    To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

translated_dialog: This will be remembered as a holy day. I wish to God that all troubles could end this well. But I must also ask your Highness to pardon your brother Clarence.
og_response: Why, madam, have I offered love for this,To be so flouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?

translated_dialog: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be mocked in front of the king? Who doesn't know that the gentle duke is dead?
og_response: You do him injury to scorn his corse.

translated_dialog: You do him wrong to joke about his death.
og_response: Who knows not he is dead! Who knows he is?

translated_dialog: Who doesn't know that he's dead? Who knew that he was!
og_response: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!

translated_dialog: Oh all-seeing God, what a terrible world!
og_response: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

translated_dialog: Do I look as pale as everyone else, Lord Dorset?
og_response: Ay, my good lord, and no one in the presenceBut his red color hath forsook his cheeks.

translated_dialog: Yes, my good lord. Everyone here in the king's presence has gone totally pale.
og_response: Is Clarence dead? The order was reversed.

translated_dialog: Is Clarence dead? The death sentence had been reversed.
og_response: But he, poor man, by your first order died,    And that a wingèd Mercury did bear.    Some tardy cripple bear the countermand,    That came too lag to see him burièd.    God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,    Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood,    Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,    And yet go current from suspicion.

translated_dialog: But Clarence died by your first order, the poor man. The death sentence must have been carried by Mercury, the winged messenger god, while the counter-order was carried by some slow cripple. It arrived too late even for his burial. It seems that someone less noble and less loyalnearer in bloody thoughts but not a blood relationdeserves the punishment that poor Clarence got, but instead goes free without suspicion.
og_response: [kneeling]  A boon, my sovereign, for my service done.

translated_dialog: [Kneeling] I must ask you a favor in return for the service I've done for you, my king.
og_response: I prithee, peace. My soul is full of sorrow.

translated_dialog: Quiet, please. My soul is full of sorrow.
og_response: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.

translated_dialog: I will not rise until your Highness hears my request.
og_response: Then say at once what is it thou requests.

translated_dialog: Then quickly say what it is you want.
og_response: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servants life,Who slew today a riotous gentlemanLately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.

translated_dialog: I ask you to spare the life of my servant, who just today killed a rowdy gentleman that used to serve the Duke of Norfolk.
og_response: Have I a tongue to doom my brothers death,    And shall the tongue give pardon to a slave?    My brother killed no man; his fault was thought,    And yet his punishment was bitter death.    Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath,    Kneeled at my feet, and bade me be advised?    Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love?    Who told me how the poor soul did forsake    The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?    Who told me, in the field by Tewkesbury,    When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,    And said Dear brother, live, and be a king?    Who told me, when we both lay in the field    Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me    Even in his garments and did give himself,    All thin and naked, to the numb-cold night?    All this from my remembrance brutish wrath    Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you    Had so much grace to put it in my mind.    But when your carters or your waiting vassals    Have done a drunken slaughter and defaced    The precious image of our dear Redeemer,    You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon,    And I, unjustly too, must grant it you.     [STANLEY rises]     But for my brother, not a man would speak,    Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself    For him, poor soul.   The proudest of you all    Have been beholding to him in his life,    Yet none of you would once beg for his life.    O God, I fear Thy justice will take hold    On me and you, and mine and yours for this!    Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.    Ah, poor Clarence.

translated_dialog: I was willing to condemn my own brother to death, and now you want me to pardon a servant? My brother Clarence didn't kill anyone. His only fault was his ideas, and yet he was punished with bitter death. Who pled on his behalf?  When I was so angry, who kneeled at my feet and asked me to think about what I was doing? Who spoke to me about brotherhood? Who spoke about love? Who told me how the poor soul abandoned his father-in-lawthe mighty Earl of Warwickto come fight for me? Who told me of the battlefield at Tewkesbury, where Clarence rescued me when Oxford had me down, saying, "Dear brother, live, and be a king?" Who told me how, when we both lay in the field almost freezing to death, he wrapped me in his own clothes and left himself naked, exposed to the mercy of the numbingly cold night? All this seemed erased from my memory in my brutish rage, and not a man of you had the grace to remind me. But when your servants drunkenly kill someone and scorn the law of our dear Christ, you immediately get on your knees and beg, "pardon, pardon." And I, unfair as I am, must give it to you. [Stanley rises] But no one spoke on behalf my brother, and I didn't speak to myself on his behalf either, the poor soul. Even the proudest among you owed him something, and yet none of you would beg for his life. Oh God, I fear that your justice will punish me and all these gathered here, and our families as well, because of this!
og_response: This is the fruits of rashness. Marked you not    How that the guilty kindred of the queen    Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?    O, they did urge it still unto the king.    God will revenge it.   Come, lords, will you go    To comfort Edward with our company?

translated_dialog: This sorrow is the result of recklessness. Didn't you notice how the queen's guilty relatives turned pale when they heard about Clarence's death? Oh, they were always urging the king to do it. God will revenge it. Come, lords, will you come with me to comfort Edward with our companionship?
og_response: We wait upon your Grace.

translated_dialog: Good grandmother, tell us, is our father dead?
og_response: No, boy.

translated_dialog: No, boy.
og_response: Why do you weep so oft, and beat your breast,And cry, O Clarence, my unhappy son?

translated_dialog: Then why do you weep so often, and beat your chest, and cry, "Oh, Clarence, my unlucky son?"
og_response: Why do you look on us and shake your head,And call us orphans, wretches, castaways,If that our noble father were alive?

translated_dialog: If our noble father is still alive, why do you look at us and shake your head, and call us orphans, wretches, and castaways?
og_response: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.    I do lament the sickness of the king,    As loath to lose him, not your fathers death.    It were lost sorrow to wail one thats lost.

translated_dialog: My pretty grandchildren, you both misunderstand me. I'm lamenting the sickness of the king, because I don't want to lose him. I'm not lamenting your father's death. It would be wasted sorrow to cry over someone who's already dead.
og_response: Then, you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.    The king mine uncle is to blame for it.    God will revenge it, whom I will importune    With earnest prayers, all to that effect.

translated_dialog: Then, my grandmother, you're admitting that our father is dead. My uncle, the king, is to blame for it. God will revenge it, and I'll pray earnestly every day that he does so.
og_response: And so will I.

translated_dialog: And so will I.
og_response: Peace, children, peace. The king doth love you well.Incapable and shallow innocents,You cannot guess who caused your fathers death.

translated_dialog: Quiet, children, quiet. The king loves you both very much. You innocent, naive children, you cannot guess who caused your father's death.
og_response: Grandam, we can, for my good uncle Gloucester    Told me the king, provoked to it by the queen,    Devised impeachments to imprison him;    And when my uncle told me so, he wept,    And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek,    Bade me rely on him as on my father,    And he would love me dearly as a child.

translated_dialog: But we can, grandmother, for my good uncle Richard told me. He said that the king was provoked by the queen to make up accusations against my father that would get him arrested. When my uncle told me about this he wept, and pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek. He told me that I could rely on him as if he were my father, and that he would love me as dearly as if I were his child.
og_response: Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape,    And with a virtuous visor hide deep vice.    He is my son, ay, and therein my shame,    Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

translated_dialog: Ah, it's terrible that liars can steal the appearance of gentle people, and hide their wickedness under a virtuous mask. Yes, he is my son. And in being my son, he is the source of my shame as a mother. But he didn't get his deceitfulness from my breast.
og_response: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

translated_dialog: Do you think that my uncle was lying, grandmother?
og_response: Ay, boy.

translated_dialog: Yes, boy.
og_response: I cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this?

translated_dialog: I can't believe it. Wait, what's that noise?
og_response: Ah, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,    To chide my fortune and torment myself?    Ill join with black despair against my soul    And to myself become an enemy.

translated_dialog: Ah, who can stop me from wailing and weeping, cursing my bad luck, and tormenting myself? I'll ally myself with the black despair that threatens my soul, and become my own enemy.
og_response: What means this scene of rude impatience?

translated_dialog: What do you mean by this melodramatic scene?
og_response: To make an act of tragic violence.    Edward, my lord, thy son, our king, is dead.    Why grow the branches when the root is gone?    Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?    If you will live, lament. If die, be brief,    That our swift-wingèd souls may catch the kings,    Or, like obedient subjects, follow him    To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.

translated_dialog: I'm performing the violent tragedy of my life. Edwardmy husband, your son, our kingis dead. Why should we keep living when our leader and lifeblood is gone? How can the branches keep growing when the root is gone? Why aren't the leaves withering now that the sap is dried up? If you will live, then lament. If you will die, then be quick about it, so our swift-winged souls might catch up with the king'sor at least follow him, like obedient subjects, into his new kingdom of never-ending night.
og_response: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow    As I had title in thy noble husband.    I have bewept a worthy husbands death    And lived with looking on his images;    But now two mirrors of his princely semblance    Are cracked in pieces by malignant death,    And I, for comfort, have but one false glass    That grieves me when I see my shame in him.    Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother,    And hast the comfort of thy children left,    But death hath snatched my husband from mine arms    And plucked two crutches from my feeble hands,    Clarence and Edward.   O, what cause have I,    Thine being but a moiety of my moan,    To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!

translated_dialog: Ah, I was your noble husband's mother, so I have just as large a share in your grief. I've already wept over my own worthy husband's death and kept myself alive only by looking at his sons, his mirror images. But now two of those mirrors have been cracked into pieces by death, and the only one left to comfort me is Richardan untrustworthy mirror who only causes me shame and grief. You are a widow, but you're also a mother, and you still have the comfort of your children left. But death has snatched my husband from my arms and then plucked my two crutches, Clarence and Edward, from my feeble hands. Oh, I have every reason to surpass you in sorrow and drown out your weeping with my own, as your loss is only half of mine!
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]  Ah, aunt, you wept not for our fathers death.How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

translated_dialog: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Oh, Aunt, you didn't weep for our father's death. So why would we help you with our tears?
og_response: Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned. Your widow-dolor likewise be unwept!

translated_dialog: You didn't mourn with us when we were left fatherless. Your sadness as a widow will likewise go unmourned by us!
og_response: G   ive me no help in lamentation.    I am not barren to bring forth complaints.    All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,    That I, being governed by the watery moon,    May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world.    Ah, for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!

translated_dialog: I don't need any help in mourning. I am full of sorrows to complain about. May all the earth's springs keep my eyes replenished with tears, so that when the tide is high in the ocean of my weeping, I can drown the world. Ah, for my husband, my dear lord Edward!
og_response: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

translated_dialog: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
og_response: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

translated_dialog: Alas for both Edward and Clarence, both mine!
og_response: What stay had I but Edward? And hes gone.

translated_dialog: What support did I have besides Edward? And he's dead.
og_response: What stay had we but Clarence? And hes gone.

translated_dialog: What support did we have besides Clarence? And he's dead.
og_response: What stays had I but they? And they are gone.

translated_dialog: What supports did I have besides both of them? And they are dead.
og_response: Was never widow had so dear a loss.

translated_dialog: A widow never suffered so great a loss.
og_response: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.

translated_dialog: Orphans never suffered so great a loss.
og_response: Was never mother had so dear a loss.    Alas, I am the mother of these griefs.    Their woes are parceled; mine are general.    She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;    I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.    These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;    I for an Edward weep; so do not they.    Alas, you three, on me, threefold distressed,    Pour all your tears. I am your sorrows nurse,    And I will pamper it with lamentations.

translated_dialog: A mother never suffered so great a loss. Alas, I am the mother of these griefs. Each of you has only a single loss, while I suffer all of them. Elizabeth weeps for Edward, and so do I, but she does not weep for Clarence like I do. These children weep for Clarence, and so do I, but they don't weep for Edward like I do. You three should pour all your tears onto me. I will be your sorrow's nurse, and feed your tears with more mourning.
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]      Comfort, dear mother. God is    much displeased    That you take with unthankfulness, his doing.    In common worldly things, tis called ungrateful    With dull unwillingness to repay a debt    Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;    Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,    For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

translated_dialog: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Dear Mother, let yourself be comforted. God is displeased that you respond to his doings so unthankfully. In everyday business, it's considered ungrateful if someone is unwilling to repay a debt which was generously loaned in the first place. It's much worse to be so opposed to heaven, now that it requires the royal debt it lent to you.
og_response: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother,    Of the young prince your son.   Send straight for him.    Let him be crowned. In him your comfort lives.    Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edwards grave    And plant your joys in living Edwards throne.

translated_dialog: Madam, think of your son, the young prince, and be a careful mother. Send for him right away. Let him be crowned king. He is your hope for future peace of mind. Drown your desperate sorrows in dead Edward's grave, and plant your future joys in Prince Edward's new throne.
og_response: Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause    To wail the dimming of our shining star,    But none can help our harms by wailing them.    Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy;    I did not see your Grace.   Humbly on my knee    I crave your blessing.

translated_dialog: Sister, let yourself be comforted. All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of the king, our shining star, but none of us can help anything by wailing.
og_response: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast,Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.

translated_dialog: God bless you, and fill you with humility, love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
og_response: [standing]  Amen.  [aside]  And make me die a good old man! That is the butt end of a mothers blessing;I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.

translated_dialog: [Standing up] Amen.
og_response: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers    That bear this heavy mutual load of moan,    Now cheer each other in each others love.    Though we have spent our harvest of this king,    We are to reap the harvest of his son.    The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates,    But lately splintered, knit, and joined together,    Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.    Meseemeth good that with some little train    Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet    Hither to London, to be crowned our king.

translated_dialog: You weeping princes and sorrowful nobles who bear this mutual weight of grief, let us now cheer each other up with our love. Though we have lost our old, fruitful king, we will now reap the harvest of his son. Our former hatreds were only recently broken and then rejoined as friendship, and now we must gently preserve, cherish, and keep this new goodwill. It seems like a good idea that a small group of us should now set out for Ludlow Castle in Wales, to fetch the young prince and bring him here to London, where he will be crowned our king.
og_response: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

translated_dialog: Why only a "small group," my Lord of Buckingham?
og_response: Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude    The new-healed wound of malice should break out,    Which would be so much the more dangerous    By how much the estate is green and yet ungoverned.    Where every horse bears his commanding rein    And may direct his course as please himself,    As well the fear of harm as harm apparent,    In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

translated_dialog: Well, my lord, if a large group goes, the newly-healed hostilities between us might break out again. This could be very dangerous, as the Yorkist rule is still new and untested. We should prevent a situation where it seems like every man is out for himself, with everyone paranoid about imagined enemies.
og_response: I hope the king made peace with all of us;And the compact is firm and true in me.

translated_dialog: The king tried to make peace among all of us, and I hope he succeeded. For me, at least, those vows of friendship were firm and true.
og_response: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.    Yet since it is but green, it should be put    To no apparent likelihood of breach,    Which haply by much company might be urged.    Therefore I say with noble Buckingham    That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.

translated_dialog: And for me also. And so, I think, for all of us. But since our agreement is so fresh, we shouldn't risk putting it under too much stresswhich might happen if all of us go at once to fetch the prince. So I agree with noble Buckingham that it's best for only a few to go.
og_response: And so say I.

translated_dialog: And I agree.
og_response: Then be it so, and go we to determine    Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.    Madam, and you, my sister, will you go    To give your censures in this business?

translated_dialog: Then we'll do that. Now let's go and figure out which of us will ride off to Ludlow.
og_response: My lord, whoever journeys to the prince,    For Gods sake let not us two at home.    For by the way Ill sort occasion,    As index to the story we late talked of,    To part the queens proud kindred from the prince.

translated_dialog: My lord, whoever ends up journeying to meet the prince, for God's sake let us be part of the group. Along the way I'll create an opportunity to separate him from the queen's proud relativesas the first step in the plan we discussed recently.
og_response: My other self, my councils consistory,    My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin,    I, as a child, will go by thy direction    Toward Ludlow then, for well not stay behind.

translated_dialog: Good morning, neighbor. Where are you hurrying off to?
og_response: I promise you I scarcely know myself.Hear you the news abroad?

translated_dialog: I swear, I hardly know where I'm going myself. Have you heard the news going around?
og_response: Yes, that the king is dead.

translated_dialog: Yes, that the king is dead.
og_response: Ill news, by 'r Lady. Seldom comes the better. I fear, I fear, twill prove a giddy world.

translated_dialog: Bad news, by the Virgin Mary. The news is always bad, and likely to get worse. I fear that the world will go crazy.
og_response: Neighbors, God speed.

translated_dialog: Hello, neighbors.
og_response: Give you good morrow, sir.

translated_dialog: Good morning to you, sir.
og_response: Doth this news hold of good King Edwards death?

translated_dialog: Is the news true that good King Edward has died?
og_response: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.

translated_dialog: Yes, sir, it's too true, God help us.
og_response: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

translated_dialog: Then be ready for troubled times, sirs.
og_response: No, no, by Gods good grace, his son shall reign.

translated_dialog: No, no, by God's good grace, his son will become king.
og_response: Woe to the land thats governed by a child.

translated_dialog: It's bad for a country to be ruled by a child.
og_response: In him there is a hope of government,    Which, in his nonage, council under him,    And, in his full and ripened years, himself,    No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.

translated_dialog: There is hope for the country under his rule, though. A young king who governs wisely under his advisors will govern wisely on his own when he reaches adulthood.
og_response: So stood the state when Henry the SixthWas crowned in Paris but at nine months old.

translated_dialog: That's how it went when Henry the Sixth was crowned in Paris at just nine months old.
og_response: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot,    For then this land was famously enriched    With politic grave counsel; then the king    Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace.

translated_dialog: Is that how it was? No, no, good friends, back then the country was rich with intelligent advisors, and the king had virtuous uncles to protect him.
og_response: Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.

translated_dialog: Why, this kingEdward's sonhas uncles too, on both his father's and his mother's side.
og_response: Better it were they all came by his father,    Or by the father there were none at all,    For emulation who shall now be nearest    Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.    O, full of danger is the duke of Gloucester,    And the queens sons and brothers haught and proud,    And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,    This sickly land might solace as before.

translated_dialog: It would be better if they were all on his father's side, or if none at all were on his father's side. For as it is, the contest over which uncles will be closest to the king is likely to affect all of us, if God doesn't prevent it. The Duke of GloucesterRichardis a dangerous man. And Queen Elizabeth's sons and brothers are haughty and proud. This sickly country will only have a chance of being healed if they end up as subjects, not rulers.
og_response: Come, come, we fear the worst. All will be well.

translated_dialog: Come, come, we're worrying about the worst possible outcome. I'm sure that everything will be all right.
og_response: When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks;    When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand;    When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?    Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.    All may be well; but if God sort it so,    'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.

translated_dialog: You know what they say: when clouds appear, wise men put on their coats. When leaves fall from the trees, winter is coming. When the sun sets, who doesn't expect night? When storms arrive early, men expect a bad harvest. Everything may be all right, as you say. But if God wills it to turn out all right, that will be more than we deserve, and not what I expect.
og_response: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear.Ye cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of dread.

translated_dialog: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear. There's hardly anyone who isn't unreasonably worried right now.
og_response: Before the days of change, still is it so.    By a divine instinct, mens minds mistrust    Ensuing dangers,   as by proof we see    The water swell before a boist'rous storm.    But leave it all to God. Whither away?

translated_dialog: It's always like this before times of great change. By some divine instinct, we get nervous when danger is comingjust like when we see the waves swelling before a storm arrives. But leave it all to God. Where are you off to?
og_response: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.

translated_dialog: Indeed, the judges have sent for us.
og_response: And so was I. Ill bear you company.

translated_dialog: I hear that last night they slept at Stony Stratford, and tonight they'll rest in Northampton. Tomorrow or the next day they'll be here.
og_response: I long with all my heart to see the prince. I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

translated_dialog: I long with all my heart to see the prince. I hope he's grown a lot since the last time I saw him.
og_response: But I hear no; they say my son of YorkHas almost overta'en him in his growth.

translated_dialog: I heard he hasn't though. They say that my son of York has almost passed him in height.
og_response: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.

translated_dialog: Yes, Mother, but I wish it weren't so.
og_response: Why, my young cousin? It is good to grow.

translated_dialog: Why, my child? It is good to grow.
og_response: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper,    My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow    More than my brother:   Ay, quoth my uncle Gloucester,    Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.    And since, methinks I would not grow so fast    Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.

translated_dialog: Grandmother, one night while we were eating dinner, my uncle Rivers mentioned that I had grown more than my brother. "Yes," said my uncle Richard, "Small herbs grow with grace, while big weeds grow quickly." And since then, I've wished that I wouldn't grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow, and weeds are hasty.
og_response: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold    In him that did object the same to thee!    He was the wretchedst thing when he was young,    So long a-growing and so leisurely,    That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.

translated_dialog: Honestly, honestly, that saying certainly didn't hold true for Richard! He was a terrible child, and took such a long time to grow up that if that rule were true, he should be a very gracious adult.
og_response: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

translated_dialog: And no doubt he is, my gracious madam.
og_response: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.

translated_dialog: I hope he is, but mothers can have their doubts.
og_response: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered,I could have given my uncles grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.

translated_dialog: Now, if I'd considered something I once heard about him, I could have scoffed at my uncleand mocked his growth more than he mocked mine.
og_response: How, my pretty York? I prithee let me hear it.

translated_dialog: How, my clever York? Let me hear your comeback.
og_response: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast    That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.    'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.    Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

translated_dialog: Well, they say that my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw a crust of bread at two hours old. For me, it took two full years before I could get a single tooth. Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.
og_response: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?

translated_dialog: Please tell me, clever York, who told you this about him?
og_response: Grandam, his nurse.

translated_dialog: His nurse, grandmother.
og_response: His nurse? Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.

translated_dialog: His nurse? Why, she was dead before you were born.
og_response: If twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

translated_dialog: If it wasn't her, then I can't say who told me.
og_response: A parlous boy! Go to, you are too shrewd.

translated_dialog: A cunning boy! Get out of here, you're too clever for your own good.
og_response: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

translated_dialog: Good madam, don't be angry with the child.
og_response: Pitchers have ears.

translated_dialog: Little pitchers have wide ears.
og_response: Here comes a messenger. What news?

translated_dialog: Here comes a messenger.
og_response: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.

translated_dialog: It's news that grieves me to report, my lord.
og_response: How doth the prince?

translated_dialog: How is the prince?
og_response: Well, madam, and in health.

translated_dialog: Madam, he's well and in good health.
og_response: What is thy news then?

translated_dialog: What's your news then?
og_response: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,And, with them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

translated_dialog: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey have been sent to Pomfret, and Sir Thomas Vaughan with them. They're all prisoners.
og_response: Who hath committed them?

translated_dialog: Who had them arrested?
og_response: The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.

translated_dialog: The mighty dukes of Gloucester and Buckingham.
og_response: For what offence?

translated_dialog: For what crime?
og_response: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.Why, or for what, the nobles were committedIs all unknown to me, my gracious lord.

translated_dialog: I've told you all that I know. Why the nobles were arrested, and on what charges, is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
og_response: Ay me! I see the ruin of my house.    The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind.    Insulting tyranny begins to jut    Upon the innocent and aweless throne.    Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.    I see, as in a map, the end of all.

translated_dialog: God help us! I see the ruin of my family. The tiger has now seized the gentle deer. Brute tyranny begins to attack the innocent, weak throne. Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre! I can see how this will end as clearly as if I was reading it on a map.
og_response: Accursèd and unquiet wrangling days,    How many of you have mine eyes beheld?    My husband lost his life to get the crown,    And often up and down my sons were tossed    For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.    And being seated, and domestic broils    Clean overblown, themselves the conquerors    Make war upon themselves, brother to brother,    Blood to blood, self against self.   O, preposterous    And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen,    Or let me die, to look on death no more.

translated_dialog: Oh, how many cursed and violent days of unrest have my old eyes seen? My husband lost his life to get the crown. And my sons' lives have been tossed up and down for me to rejoice over their gains and weep over their losses. And when one of them gained the throne and got rid of the domestic quarrels, now the conquerors turn on each other, making war among themselvesbrother against brother, blood against blood, self against self. Oh, it's a perversion of the natural order, a frenzied outrage! Let it endor let me dieso I won't have to see any more death.
og_response: [to YORK]  Come, come, my boy. We will to sanctuary.Madam, farewell.

translated_dialog: [To YORK] Come, come, my boy. We'll go take sanctuary. Madam, farewell.
og_response: Stay, I will go with you.

translated_dialog: Wait, I will go with you.
og_response: You have no cause.

translated_dialog: You have no reason to.
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]     My gracious lady, go,    And thither bear your treasure and your goods.    For my part, Ill resign unto your Grace    The seal I keep; and so betide to me    As well I tender you and all of yours.    Go. Ill conduct you to the sanctuary.

translated_dialog: Welcome to your room here in London, sweet prince.
og_response: [to PRINCE]  Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign.The weary way hath made you melancholy.

translated_dialog: Welcome, dear nephew, ruler of my thoughts. It seems that the tiring journey has made you sad.
og_response: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.I want more uncles here to welcome me.

translated_dialog: No, uncle, but the annoyances on the way made the journey tedious, tiring, and dull. I wish more uncles were here to welcome me.
og_response: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years    Hath not yet dived into the worlds deceit;    Nor more can you distinguish of a man    Than of his outward show, which, God He knows,    Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.    Those uncles which you want were dangerous.    Your Grace attended to their sugared words    But looked not on the poison of their hearts.    God keep you from them, and from such false friends.

translated_dialog: Sweet prince, you are young and innocent, and haven't experienced the deceitfulness of the world yet. You can't perceive the truth about a man except for what he shows on the outsidewhich, God knows, hardly ever corresponds with his heart. Those uncles you wish for were dangerous. You heard their sugary words, but you couldn't see the poison in their hearts, your Grace. May God protect you from them, and from all such false friends!
og_response: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.

translated_dialog: May God protect me from false friendsbut my uncles weren't false.
og_response: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

translated_dialog: My lord, the mayor of London is here to greet you.
og_response: God bless your Grace with health and happy days.

translated_dialog: May God bless your Grace with health and happy days.
og_response: I thank you, good my lord, and thank you all.    I thought my mother and my brother York    Would long ere this have met us on the way.    Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not    To tell us whether they will come or no!

translated_dialog: I thank you, my good lord, and thank you all. But I thought my mother and my brother York would have met us on our way long before now. And it's shameful what a slug Hastings is, that he hasn't even come to tell us whether or not they're coming!
og_response: And in good time here comes the sweating lord.

translated_dialog: And just in time, here comes the sweating lord.
og_response: Welcome, my lord. What, will our mother come?

translated_dialog: Welcome, my lord. Well, is my mother coming?
og_response: On what occasion God He knows, not I,    The Queen your mother and your brother York    Have taken sanctuary.   The tender prince    Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace,    But by his mother was perforce withheld.

translated_dialog: Only God knows why, but the queen your mother and your brother York have taken sanctuary in Westminster Abbey. The tender prince wanted to come with me to meet your Grace, but his mother forced him to stay.
og_response: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course    Is this of hers!   Lord Cardinal, will your Grace    Persuade the queen to send the duke of York    Unto his princely brother presently?    If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,    And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

translated_dialog: For shame, what a devious and perverse course the queen is taking!
og_response: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory    Can from his mother win the duke of York,    Anon expect him here;   but if she be obdurate    To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid    We should infringe the holy privilege    Of blessèd sanctuary!   Not for all this land    Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

translated_dialog: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak words can persuade his mother to give up the Duke of York, then you can expect him here soon. But if she resists my mild requests, then God forbid that we should break the holy laws of sanctuary! I would not commit such a terrible sin even in exchange for a kingdom.
og_response: You are too senseless obstinate, my lord,    Too ceremonious and traditional.    Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,    You break not sanctuary in seizing him.    The benefit thereof is always granted    To those whose dealings have deserved the place    And those who have the wit to claim the place.    This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it    And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.    Then taking him from thence that is not there,    You break no privilege nor charter there.    Oft have I heard of sanctuary men,    But sanctuary children, ne'er till now.

translated_dialog: My lord, you are foolishly stubborn, and too tied to formalities and traditions. Consider the moral roughness of these times, and you'll see that you're not really breaking sanctuary in seizing him. The benefit of sanctuary is always given to those who really deserve protection, or those who are smart enough to claim it. This prince has neither claimed it nor does he deserve it. Therefore, in my opinion, he cannot have it. If you seize him from sanctuary when he was never really taking sanctuary in the first place, then you aren't breaking any laws or traditions. I've often heard of "sanctuary men," but until now I've never heard of "sanctuary children."
og_response: My lord, you shall o'errule my mind for once.Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

translated_dialog: My lord, I'll let you convince me this once.
og_response: I go, my lord.

translated_dialog: I will, my lord.
og_response: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.

translated_dialog: Good lords, go as quickly as you can.
og_response: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

translated_dialog: Tell me, Uncle Richard: if my brother comes, where will we stay until my coronation ceremony?
og_response: Where it seems best unto your royal self.    If I may counsel you, some day or two    Your Highness shall repose you at the Tower;    Then where you please and shall be thought most fit    For your best health and recreation.

translated_dialog: Wherever seems best for your royal self. If I can advise you, though, you should stay a day or two in the Tower. After that you can stay wherever you like, and wherever seems best for your health and pleasure.
og_response: I do not like the Tower, of any place.Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

translated_dialog: Of all places, I don't like the Tower at all. Didn't Julius Caesar build it, my lord?
og_response: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place,Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

translated_dialog: He began it, my gracious lord. And since then succeeding generations have added on to it.
og_response: Is it upon record, or else reportedSuccessively from age to age, he built it?

translated_dialog: Is it on record that he built the Tower, or is it just reported by word of mouth from generation to generation?
og_response: Upon record, my gracious lord.

translated_dialog: On record, my gracious lord.
og_response: But say, my lord, it were not registered,    Methinks the truth should live from age to age,    As twere retailed to all posterity,    Even to the general all-ending day.

translated_dialog: But even if it weren't recorded, I think that the truth would live on from generation to generationbeing told as part of legend and historyall the way until Judgment Day.
og_response: [aside]  So wise so young, they say, do never live long.

translated_dialog: [To himself] They say that those who are so wise when so young never live long.
og_response: What say you, uncle?

translated_dialog: What did you say, uncle?
og_response: I say, without characters fame lives long.  [aside]  Thus, like the formal Vice, Iniquity,I moralize two meanings in one word.

translated_dialog: I said that without written records, fame lives long.
og_response: That Julius Caesar was a famous man.    With what his valor did enrich his wit,    His wit set down to make his valor live.    Death makes no conquest of this conqueror,    For now he lives in fame, though not in life.    Ill tell you what, my cousin Buckingham

translated_dialog: That Julius Caesar was a famous man. His courage aided his intelligence, and his intelligence helped him make sure that his reputation for courage outlived him. Death didn't conquer that conqueror. Now he lives on in fame, though not in life. I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham
og_response: What, my gracious lord?

translated_dialog: What, my gracious lord?
og_response: An if I live until I be a man,Ill win our ancient right in France againOr die a soldier, as I lived a king.

translated_dialog: If I live to be a man, I'll conquer France and win back our claim to the throne there. Otherwise I'll die as a soldier, though I lived as a king.
og_response: [aside]  Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

translated_dialog: [To himself] Short summers often have an early spring, as they say. Those who die young are usually precocious.
og_response: Now in good time here comes the duke of York.

translated_dialog: Now here comes the Duke of York, right on time.
og_response: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?

translated_dialog: Richard of York, how are you, my loving brother?
og_response: Well, my dread lordso must I call you now.

translated_dialog: I'm well, my sovereign lordfor that's what I must call you now.
og_response: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours.Too late he died that might have kept that title, Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

translated_dialog: Yes, Brother, and it's a sad occasion for both of us. Our fatherthe man who should have kept that titledied too recently. And the sadness of his death makes the title seem much less majestic.
og_response: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

translated_dialog: How are you, my nephew, noble Lord of York?
og_response: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

translated_dialog: I thank you for asking, noble uncle. Oh, my lord, you once said that lazy weeds grow quickly. The prince my brother has far outgrown me.
og_response: He hath, my lord.

translated_dialog: He has, my lord.
og_response: And therefore is he idle?

translated_dialog: So is he lazy then?
og_response: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

translated_dialog: Oh, my fair nephew, I can't say that.
og_response: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

translated_dialog: Then he has more power over you than I do.
og_response: He may command me as my sovereign,But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

translated_dialog: He may command me as my king, but you still have power over me as my relative.
og_response: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

translated_dialog: Please give me your dagger, uncle.
og_response: My dagger, little cousin? With all my heart.

translated_dialog: My dagger, little Nephew? With all my heart.
og_response: A beggar, brother?

translated_dialog: Are you begging, Brother?
og_response: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give,And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

translated_dialog: Only from my kind uncle. I know he'll give it to me, and it's not valuable, so it shouldn't make him sad to lose it.
og_response: A greater gift than that Ill give my cousin.

translated_dialog: I'll give my nephew a greater gift than that.
og_response: A greater gift? O, thats the sword to it.

translated_dialog: A greater gift? Oh, that must mean a sword.
og_response: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.

translated_dialog: Yes, noble nephew. That is, if it's light enough for you to hold.
og_response: O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.In weightier things youll say a beggar nay.

translated_dialog: Oh, then I see that you'll only part with light, trivial gifts. You'll refuse a beggar's request in heavier, more valuable things.
og_response: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.

translated_dialog: A sword is too heavy for your Grace to wear.
og_response: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

translated_dialog: I'd consider it light and trivial even if it were heavier.
og_response: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

translated_dialog: What, do you want my weapon, little lord?
og_response: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

translated_dialog: I do, so I can thank you for what you called me.
og_response: How?

translated_dialog: What do you mean?
og_response: Little.

translated_dialog: You called me "little."
og_response: My lord of York will still be cross in talk.Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.

translated_dialog: The Lord of York is always argumentative. Uncle, you know how to bear with him.
og_response: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me.    Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me.    Because that I am little, like an ape,    He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

translated_dialog: You mean to bear me, not to bear with me.
og_response: [aside]    With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!    To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,    He prettily and aptly taunts himself.    So cunning and so young is wonderful.

translated_dialog: [To himself] What a sharp and thoughtful mind he has! To smooth over his mockery of his uncle, he cleverly and politely mocks himself. It's amazing that he's so cunning while so young.
og_response: [to PRINCE]    My lord, will t please you pass along?    Myself and my good cousin Buckingham    Will to your mother, to entreat of her    To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

translated_dialog: [To the PRINCE] My lord, would you like to continue on? My good cousin Buckingham and I will go to your mother and ask her to meet you at the Tower.
og_response: [to PRINCE]  What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

translated_dialog: [To the PRINCE] What, are you going to the Tower, my lord?
og_response: My lord protector needs will have it so.

translated_dialog: My Lord Protector Richard insists on it.
og_response: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

translated_dialog: I won't sleep peacefully at the Tower.
og_response: Why, what should you fear?

translated_dialog: Why, what do you have to be afraid of?
og_response: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost. My grandam told me he was murdered there.

translated_dialog: Well, my uncle Clarence's angry ghost. My grandmother told me he was murdered there.
og_response: I fear no uncles dead.

translated_dialog: I'm not afraid of any dead uncle.
og_response: Nor none that live, I hope.

translated_dialog: Nor living ones, I hope.
og_response: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.  [to YORK]  But come, my lord. With a heavy heart,Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

translated_dialog: If they're still alive, I should hope that I don't need to fear them.
og_response: Think you, my lord, this little prating YorkWas not incensèd by his subtle motherTo taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

translated_dialog: My lord, don't you think that this talkative little York was encouraged by his deceitful mother to taunt and scorn you in that outrageous manner?
og_response: No doubt, no doubt. O, tis a parlous boy,Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable. He is all the mothers, from the top to toe.

translated_dialog: No doubt, no doubt. Oh, he's a dangerous and cunning boybold, lively, ingenious, outspoken, and capable. He takes after his mother, from head to toe.
og_response: Well, let them rest.   Come hither, Catesby.    Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend    As closely to conceal what we impart.    Thou knowest our reasons, urged upon the way.    What thinkest thou?   Is it not an easy matter    To make William Lord Hastings of our mind    For the installment of this noble duke    In the seat royal of this famous isle?

translated_dialog: Well, let's leave them for the moment.
og_response: He, for his fathers sake, so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him.

translated_dialog: Hastings loves the Prince because of his great love for his father, the late King Edward. We won't be able to convince him.
og_response: What thinkst thou then of Stanley? Will not he?

translated_dialog: What do you think about Stanley then? Won't he join us?
og_response: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

translated_dialog: He'll do whatever Hastings does.
og_response: Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,    And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings    How he doth stand affected to our purpose    And summon him tomorrow to the Tower    To sit about the coronation.    If thou dost find him tractable to us,    Encourage him and show him all our reasons.    If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling,    Be thou so too, and so break off the talk,    And give us notice of his inclination;    For we tomorrow hold divided councils,    Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.

translated_dialog: Well then, just do this, noble Catesby: go and sound out Lord Hastings regarding our cause. But make it seem like a vague plan for the distant future. Find out how he feels, and summon him to the Tower tomorrow for the coronation. If he seems like he could be convinced to join us, then encourage him and explain all our reasons to him. If he's surly, cold, or unwilling, then you should act like that too, and break off the conversation. Let us know how he responds, for tomorrow we will hold two separate council meetingsone public, and one in secret, only for our supportersand you'll have lots of work to do at them.
og_response: Commend me to Lord William. Tell him, Catesby,    His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries    Tomorrow are let blood at Pomfret castle,    And bid my lord, for joy of this good news,    Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

translated_dialog: Give my regards to Lord Hastings. Tell him, Catesby, that the dangerous enemies who have plagued him for years will be executed tomorrow at Pomfret Castle. And to celebrate this good news, tell him to give Miss Shore an extra kiss.
og_response: Good Catesby, go effect this business soundly.

translated_dialog: Good Catesby, go do your work well.
og_response: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.

translated_dialog: My good lords, I'll do the best I can.
og_response: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

translated_dialog: Will we hear from you before we go to sleep, Catesby?
og_response: You shall, my lord.

translated_dialog: You will, my lord.
og_response: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

translated_dialog: You'll find us both at Crosby Place.
og_response: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceiveLord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

translated_dialog: Now, my lord, what will we do if Lord Hastings won't go along with our conspiracy?
og_response: Chop off his head. Something we will determine.    And look when I am king,   claim thou of me    The earldom of Hereford,   and all the moveables    Whereof the king my brother was possessed.

translated_dialog: Chop off his head. We'll come up with something. And when I am king, you will have the earldom of Herefordand all the wealth and possessions that go with itwhich my brother, King Edward, used to own.
og_response: Ill claim that promise at your Graces hands.

translated_dialog: I'll take you up on that promise, your Grace.
og_response: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwardsWe may digest our complots in some form.

translated_dialog: [Knocking] My lord, my lord.
og_response: [within]  Who knocks?

translated_dialog: [Offstage] Who's knocking?
og_response: One from the Lord Stanley.

translated_dialog: A messenger from Lord Stanley.
og_response: [within]  What is t oclock?

translated_dialog: [Offstage] What time is it?
og_response: Upon the stroke of four.

translated_dialog: Four in the morning.
og_response: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?

translated_dialog: Can't Lord Stanley sleep on this long night?
og_response: So it appears by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble self.

translated_dialog: It appears not, based on his message. First, he sends his regards to your noble self.
og_response: What then?

translated_dialog: And what else?
og_response: Then certifies your Lordship that this night    He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm.    Besides, he says there are two councils kept,    And that may be determined at the one    Which may make you and him to rue at th' other.    Therefore he sends to know your Lordships pleasure,    If you will presently take horse with him    And with all speed post with him toward the north    To shun the danger that his soul divines.

translated_dialog: He then tells your Lordship that tonight he dreamed that the boar cut off his head. He also says that there will be two council meetings tomorrow, and that the results of one meeting may make you and Stanleywho will be at the othervery sorry indeed. Because of this, he wants to know if you'll ride with him to the north as soon as possible, to escape the danger that his soul senses.
og_response: Go, fellow, go. Return unto thy lord.    Bid him not fear the separated council.    His Honor and myself are at the one,    And at the other is my good friend Catesby,    Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us    Whereof I shall not have intelligence.    Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.    And for his dreams, I wonder hes so simple    To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers.    To fly the boar before the boar pursues    Were to incense the boar to follow us    And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.    Go, bid thy master rise and come to me,    And we will both together to the Tower,    Where he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.

translated_dialog: Go, fellow, go. Return to your lord. Tell him not to worry about the two separate meetings. He and I will be at one meeting, and my good friend Catesby will be at the other.
